Posts.Content: dgchick29 wrote: I made the choice to go ahead and make a post on these forums a little while ago. I didn't feel right in doing it because well.. I don't know. I know my chance for having cancer, whether in be in situ or otherwise, is a small chance. But after having my test results for about a week now and trying to figure out a couple things on my own, I decided to reach out. (If youre curious.. my 1st post "vague radiologist report " is in the not diagnosed but worried section) I am very interested to know if any of you have ever had this happen. Standing upright, both of my breasts look pretty much as symmetrical as they always have. HOWEVER, after noticing the discharge (which prompted the tests) I noticed when I bend over and sway back and forth..the breast in question doesn't hang quite right. It seems to be "fixed" to my skin up top. My left is very very movable. The right "lags" behind and LOOKS WISE reminds me a bit of how a water balloon would if it was over filled. I also have nipple deviation on that breast. My left is normal but my right points the opposite direction. On the inner part of my right, at the top, when I sway back and forth (when bending forward) the "tissue" is very visible. Where on the left it is not. I would really love to hear if any of you, benign results or not, have experienced this? ??!! I read to do this on a breast exam website. I know it's not a typical way to check your breasts..but I tried it one day and the difference in my breasts are unbelievable. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Breast asymmetry when bending forward? dgchick29 dgchick29

Posts.Content: dgchick29 wrote: I recently had a mammogram show an intraductal mass, which was biopsied, and turned out to be a papilloma. This was a couple weeks ago. Very relieved. Here's where I'm stumped.. my surgeon (who removed papilloma ^ is a GENERAL surgeon) did my central duct excision at our local hospital. The hospital is reputable with on-site pathologists. My surgery was same day and on my discharge papers it stated that I have ADH. I'm sure some of you are familiar with EHR'S (electronic health records through patient portals) Not only did it say that on the discharge papers but it's on all my EHR'S through the whole system in the hospital patient portal. It's listed under my "problem list" I went for my follow up with the surgeon a few days ago and he acted like he had no idea why they put it on there,as the pathology report did not mention ADH. So now.. I'm very confused. Happy that the papilloma was just that. But am still feeling in the dark about the possibility of the ADH (which I know is NOT cancer or even precancer) anyone ever had a situation like this? There was also an attending physician if that helps. I will attach my pathology report from the excision biopsy and also a pic of a random EHR from the patient portal. EVERYTHING I've read about a patient's "problem list" as far as EHR'S are concerned says that section of the EHR is VERY important and NEVER the place for a differential diagnosis, etc. Which was my first thought. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Can't get a clear answer after path report! dgchick29 dgchick29

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2016 03:51PM - edited Jul 9, 2016 03:53PM by dgchick29 I don't know which part she was referring to. She read that top paragraph and said that was another way of saying ADH. I know the duct ectasia with stasis is a dilation of the ducts. I've been knowing what that is and that I have it since my abnormal mammogram. I don't know if she was referring to the fibro cystic changes and lobular change?? I know that non proliferative fibro cystic change is fine but that proliferative fibro change can be ADH. I dunno it's frustrating trying to figure this out on my own. I shouldn't have to.
Posts.Title: Can't get a clear answer after path report! dgchick29 dgchick29

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2016 08:35PM dgchick29 wrote: I expressed my frustrations with him at follow up. I said, I did what you guys wanted me to do, in hopes of figuring this all out. He did a GREAT job with my surgery. But I asked , "WHY is adh on my problem lists??!!" He kinda threw up hid hands like he didn't know. I told him I had been researching the importance of a patient's problem list on their health records and how quick I realized..they're very important. You don't just write things of insignificance on there for no reason. Because that will be on their health record indefinitely. The only way to have it removed is if it's proven that it was added by error or through audit. As we speak.. it's still on there.
Posts.Title: Can't get a clear answer after path report! dgchick29 dgchick29

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2016 10:04PM - edited Jul 8, 2016 10:16PM by dgchick29 I have searched for each thing from my path report trying to see if it ties to ADH in some ways. But it's so exhausting and to be honest...not my job! Though I have spent countless hours trying to put the pieces together. I'm just frustrated because I figured he could explain it at the follow up but he didn't. All of the other things on my problem list are 100% accurate. I'm confused as to why this was added. Surely if it was a differential diagnosis or admitting diagnosis they would've put that somewhere other than there. Maybe the surgeon misinterperted my results wrong??? Do they usually say right on the path report if its adh?? I know ADH isn't anything but damn... I think I deserve to atleast know if I have it. Ya know?
Posts.Title: Can't get a clear answer after path report! dgchick29 dgchick29

Posts.Content: May 31, 2016 01:45AM - edited May 31, 2016 01:48AM by dgchick29 Thank you ChiSandy. I'm so relieved to see that you may know what I'm talking about lol. I resorted to asking here because there's simply a lack of information on this online. If you search "breast fixity while leaning forward" on Google, you get quite a lot of results. But I've yet to find any real women talking about it. June 3rd will make 2 weeks in between my tests and biopsy. So I've driven myself nutty trying to figure it out.i know regardless of what I find, it doesn't matter, and that I'm sure the surgeon will kn o w exactly what it is. But as I'm sure you know.. the wait can drive you to go to some crazy lengths. I guess the fact that neither my referring dr or the radiologist knew of this issue prior to my tests, to know to look for it, is somewhat unnerving. On top of me having heterogeneously dense breasts. I know I need to STOP searching and just let the surgeon guide me in the right direction. I feel so guilty knowing I'm asking in a place where women have actually been diagnosed and had their lives turned upside down by breast cancer. My issues seem so trivial. I just had to "know" if I was alone in what i know I'm seeing in the mirror . Also sorry for the long response. I'm just frustrated and will be so glad for this appt to finally get here!

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2016 09:58PM - edited Jul 8, 2016 09:58PM by dgchick29 I'm signed up for the hospitals portal as well as the surgeons. On the surgeons portal, he doesn't combine any findings/health issues from anywhere, except for what's found at his office. The hospital portal (where the ADH shows up on ALL of my health records, as well as on the discharge paper) it's pretty spot on with everything but this. Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2016 10:29PM - edited Jul 8, 2016 10:32PM by dgchick29 A bigpart of me says it was added in error. Bit it's still strange. Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2016 02:42PM dgchick29 wrote: Unbelievable! Just went for my follow up to my primary care physician. She didn't have a report of the pathology (thank God I had brought mine) and I showed it to her. I told her I felt everything went great and that I feel good about the whole thing. Except for this one thing. I showed her the path report,a couple EHRS I had printed off, and the discharge papers from the hospital. I said "will you look at my path report and tell me if anything on there indicates I have ADH?!" She looked and she was like yeah, " right here (reading from the top part of the report) this is just another way to say you have ADH" I was taken back because it just didn't make sense and still doesn't. When I asked why they wouldn't have just said, on the path report, that I have ADH. She didn't have an answer.

In the 9 o'clock position I have a cluster of small cysts. I'm having the intraductal mass biopsied. Can't imagine those small things would cause that one breast to do that. But I don't know. But yes, it's definitely new. Noticed it a couple days before my mammogram. I just didn't know to tell the tech. I thought I'd get the chance to tell the radiologist but that never happened.

Except for when sites mention do-it-yourself breast exams and tell you to lean forward to see if both breasts "fall freely." I'm assuming to check if any of your breast tissue stays attached to your chest wall/pectoral muscles. Which is exactly what I'm referring to. I do plan on talking about it (and showing) the surgeon. Matter of fact. . I'm biting at the bit to be able to. Because whether benign or otherwise. .it's definitely not normal. Was just hoping someone has experienced it too and could give me some insight! It's driving me nuts!

Posts.Content: dgchick29 wrote: I asked this question already and didn't get any responses. I think I might have went into too much detail and confused people lol. Or I'm just simply the only one that's experienced this. My biopsy is on June 3rd but I'm very curious if anyone has has this happen... My breast in question (right) does not "fall away" like they say normal breasts are supposed to do when you lean forward. It very much looks and feels like it's "fixed or stuck" in place. If that makes ANY sense. My left breast moves and falls forward very freely. The right seems like it's fixed to the tissue underneath at the top. It's very noticeable. I plan on talking to my breast surgeon when I go for my biopsy, as I didn't have that opportunity with the radiologist, when I went for my tests. Unfortunately I didn't notice it, to be able to tell my doctor, when I went in with the discharge issues in the first place. Log in to post a reply
